frameDefinitions: An Entity is designed for or exists to perform an Activity or fulfill a Role. '' 'This platform will serve as a great stage for tomorrow's play.'
Two parties, the Exchangers, each give and receive from the other Themes.
This frame concerns Stock, a purchasable and sellable asset representing a Shareholder's share in a company (the Issuer).
A Member is semi-permanently part of a socially constructed Group.
These words refer to Parts merging to form a Whole.
This frame contains words that describe a set of individuals which possess some Commonality, generally a common attribute.
frameExamples: This platform will <t>serve</t> as a great stage for tomorrow's play.
They <t>swapped</t> the island with the Neapolitan government of the day for the much smaller Capri.
My ten preferred <t>shares</t> in Google are worth more than your ten common shares in Apple.
Victor is <t>part</t> of the Red Crescent
The two droplets <t>merge</t>, and then travel down the windowpane even faster.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Entity</fen> is an object or person that performs the <fen>Activity</fen> or fulfills the <fen>Role</fen>.
The <fen>Activity</fen> is the action that the <fen>Entity</fen> performs.
The <fen>Role</fen> is  the position or duty that is occupied by the <fen>Entity</fen>.

In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, this role identifies the conversational
participant with greater semantic and syntactic prominence, as
compared with <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>. That is, <fen>Exchanger_1</fen> is generally
encoded as Subject, and peripheral FEs that do not make reference
to the event itself generally make reference to <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>. Thus
a <fen>Purpose</fen> (or <fen>Means</fen>, <fen>Depictive</fen>, or <fen>Manner</fen>) is construed to be that
of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>, not necessarily that of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> or the group
of <fen>Exchangers</fen> as a whole.

In cases where the <fen>Exchangers</fen> involved in a conversation are
construed as two separate groups with different levels of
volitionality or control, <fen>Exchanger_2</fen> refers to the semantically
and grammatically less prominent group. It is generally encoded
within a prepositional phrase (e.g. headed by with). Note that it
is possible for a single role to correspond to multiple referents.
For example, if the prepositional object in the example below were
plural, we would still assign it the single role <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.

In some sentences both participants are expressed by the Subject, and there is no 'with'-phrase (cf example 1). In sentences like this, the Subject is assigned the role role <fen>Exchangers</fen>. In such sentences, the Subject always denotes more than one person, and it is understood that the reciprocal communication takes place between these two (or more) people. The Subject may denote two or more people either through conjunction, as in example 1, or through plurality, as in example 2, or by denoting a group, as in example 3. In each of these cases the role <fen>Exchangers</fen> is assigned. Notice that for nouns in the Exchange frame, it is possible for the <fen>Exchangers</fen> role to be expressed by a prepositional phrase as in example 4.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_1</fen>.
The item that begins in the possession of <fen>Exchanger_2</fen>.
The items which change possession between the <fen>Exchangers</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the exchange takes place.
This role identifies the place where the exchange occurs.
The investment that a <fen>Shareholder</fen> makes into a business, differing from property and assets.

The the kind of <fen>Stock</fen>, of which there are two: preferred or common.  Holders of preferred stock are entitled to the first dividend that a company pays out, while holders of common stock are granted voting rights in corporate decisions.
The creditor that has invested into a business by purchasing some <fen>Type</fen> of its <fen>Stock</fen>.
The entity that issues its <fen>Stock</fen> to the <fen>Shareholder</fen>.
The person who belongs to a <fen>Group</fen>.
A set of people standing in a semi-permanent relationship together.
The time at which the <fen>Member</fen> is a member of the <fen>Group</fen>.
The location where the membership relationship holds.
The entities that merge to form a single <fen>Whole</fen>.
The single, undifferentiated entity that is the result of the amalgamation.
The prominent entity that combines with <fen>Part_2</fen> to form a <fen>Whole</fen>.
The less focussed-upon entity that the <fen>Part_1</fen> merges with.
The time at which the <fen>Parts</fen> become amalgamated into a <fen>Whole</fen>
The location at which the amalgamation occurs.

This role denotes the people in possession of the Commonality. This role is usually genetive, the object of a postnominal PP, or null instantiated (INI), and null instantiaton often implies the public at large, as in 'the common good'.
This role denotes an object or attribute which is jointly posessed by the <fen>Entities</fen>.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
listRoleExamples: The trade <fex>with Cuba</fex> went exactly as planned.
I tucked the pistol between my belt and tunic top (how I wish I had kept it, but I later swapped <fex>it</fex> with a Canadian for some cigarettes.
The organization bought the property in 1999, then swapped it with the BLM <fex>for about 100 parcels in 10 counties ranging in size from one to 920 acres</fex>.
Two <fex>members</fex> of the Red Cross were here about a donation
They had all just merged <fex>into one big file</fex>.
<fex>The single smaller soul</fex> merges with the Ur-soul.
The single smaller soul merges <fex>with the Ur-soul</fex>.
Their shared <fex>parents</fex> were their only similarity.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Film Making Tips for the Independent Filmmaker » Blog Archive » How Two Jokers De-Zombified the Film Industry with Twitter
